newsitem.title: USA: US spot natgas rises sharply on cold,storage fears.
newsitem.headline: US spot natgas rises sharply on cold,storage fears.

text.p: U.S. spot natgas prices gained an additional 30-40 cents Thursday, catapulted upward by cold U.S. weather forecasts through next week and concerns that storage supplies are not sufficient for the upcoming winter heating season, industry sources said.
Gulf Coast prices rose by about 30 cents to the mid-$3.60s to mid-$3.70s, with the lower-priced deals confirmed done late.
Many buyers said they were hesitant to venture into the December market before NYMEX's December Henry Hub contract expires this afternoon.
November business continued at a harried pace in the New York city-gate market as temperatures were forecast to remain as much as 10 degrees Fahrenheit below-normal through next week in the region.
New York prices for Friday delivery ranged anywhere from the high-$4 area early to the $4.30s late.
Indications for December 1 delivery at the New York city-gate were about $1.35-1.45 over the NYMEX screen, placing the market near $5.
American Gas Association said Wednesday that in the week ending November 15, gas stocks in the Consuming East Region fell by 58 billion cubic feet to 92 percent of capacity.

In the Midcontinent, where storage levels were about 69 percent full and temperatures still hovered below-normal, prices were up nearly 50 cents to the $3.60s and $3.70s, with some early deals done as high as $4.00.
In south Texas prices rose by more than 30 cents to the mid-$3.50s as temperatures in the region ran five to 10 degrees above-normal. More seasonable weather was anticipated at the end of week.
In west Texas, Permian prices ranged anywhere from the $3.90s to the $3.30s, up an average of 50 cents, as most supplies moved westward to the California markets.
As a result, prices at the southern California border soared into the low-$4 area early but then settled back into the $3.60s late, up an average of 40 cents from Wednesday.
Early in the session, NYMEX's December Henry Hub natural gas futures jumped to a new contract high of $3.85.
